abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rural Roads Project for
            Morocco were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was low or negligible; Bank performance
            was satisfactory; borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: in a country
            like Morocco, providing access to an all-weather road to the
            rural population requires first programs to be implemented
            by the Directorate of roads and its provincial directorates
            with a priority given to rural roads connecting to the
            network of classified roads and for the establishment of a
            platform for planning, designing and implementing rural
            roads along with an effective monitoring and evaluation
            system including impact evaluation. Implementing a national
            investment program requires the establishment of a dedicated
            and well staff unit at the onset of its launch. An adequate
            monitoring and evaluation system including well-defined and
            measurable indicators plays is key role for a successful
            program. Well stated technical standards are essential to
            the quality and sustainability of infrastructure
            investments. The preparation and dissemination a manual for
            design and appraisal of rural roads projects played a
            critical role and helped ensure quality and conformity for
            the detailed designs prepared by different and numerous consultants.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rural Roads Project
            for Morocco is to increase the level of road access by rural
            populations, especially in the Borrower's more
            disadvantaged provinces in the project area, through the
            implementation of a national program of rural roads
            development and a measure aiming at strengthening the
            Borrower's institutional capacity. The implementation
            of the project is progressing well and the change, namely an
            extension of the closing date will allow finalizing all
            activities under the project and consequently increase the
            chances of meeting the development objectives. The Bank and
            the Borrower have agreed in writing to a specific action
            plan and a schedule to complete the project within the
            extension. In this regard, the implementation schedule has
            been revised to reflect the completion of all contracts of
            the project hence the disbursement of the loan proceeds for
            the remaining period up to the new closing date of June 30,
            2011. The extension is necessary to allow: (a) the
            completion of the ongoing works that were delayed by
            exceptional weather conditions in 2007, 2008, and 2009; (b)
            the commencement and completion of works; and (c) the
            continuation of the contract concluded with the Centre
            National d'Etudes et de Recherches Routieres (CNER) for
            the monitoring and evaluation of the second national program
            of rural roads.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Roads Project for Morocco aims
            to increase rural populations' access to roads,
            especially in the more disadvantaged provinces, by
            supporting a national program of road improvements and
            through strengthening institutional capacity. The two
            components of this project are: (1) rehabilitation and/or
            upgrading of about 625 kilometers of rural roads, and (2)
            institutional development to: (a) develop monitoring and
            evaluation (M&E) of accessibility targets and execution
            of the Second National Program of Rural Roads (and roads
            improved outside this program) at the provincial and
            communal level, and disseminate the M&E information to
            further sectoral integration of rural development programs
            and strengthen local participation; (b) formulate
            recommendations for improving management of local rural
            roads to help the communes and provinces prepare to take
            over their maintenance; and (c) strengthen the capabilities
            of the Directorate of Roads for social and environmental
            assessments. This component will also include identification
            by the Provincial Directorates of Public Works (DPEs)
            together with specialized agencies, of local development
            opportunities stemming from improved accessibility, and
            assistance to the local communities.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Rural Access Roads Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rural Access Roads Project will
            improve accessibility to social, communal, and
            administrative services, thus improving the rural way of
            life. Although environmental impacts resulting from project
            implementation, are expected to be limited - the project
            will not finance activities related to deforestation,
            adversity on natural habitats, or biodiversity, nor on
            cultural sites - this environmental assessment identifies
            adverse impacts mainly during construction, and takes into
            consideration Morocco's legal and regulatory framework,
            to form the basis for the following mitigation measures.
            Natural habitats and biodiversity will be avoided,
            establishing protected areas limiting construction sites.
            Similarly, soil erosion and potential landslides would be
            avoided, taking into consideration adequate stable soils,
            and establishing drainage systems in areas prone to floods,
            while excavations should be limited during the dry season
            only. Oil spills, and lubricants should be handled and
            disposed of in accordance with standard regulations, storage
            procedures, and waste management best practices. To minimize
            air and noise pollution, re-vegetation and tree planting
            along the roads would form protective barriers limiting dust
            emissions, and noise disturbances.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Rural Access Roads Project :
            resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the framework of the Second
            National Roads Program, this Rural Access Roads Project
            seeks to reduce rural poverty, by improving accessible
            social, communal, and administrative services. While it is
            not expected that major displacements will occur due to
            project implementation, minor land acquisition and
            expropriations are foreseen, namely, expropriations on the
            right of way, and of small land plots, required for roads
            realignments. Another instrument addressing expropriations,
            often practiced in Morocco, is through voluntary donation of
            land. This resettlement policy identifies project affected
            people (PAP), and determines, based on the country's
            legislation, and the Bank's operational directive on
            involuntary resettlement, the due compensation for land, and
            asset losses (both for PAP holding property rights, or
            squatters) following public consultations. Expropriations
            will be compensated at market values as of the date of
            consignment with the authorities. Grievance mechanisms will
            be in place should conflict occur, and regular monitoring
            shall ensure compliance with his policy.

Morocco - Rural Access Roads Project :
            resettlement plan
